taglib.info: Tag library for MMBase. MMBase consists of a cloud of nodes (objects) wich can be related to each other. Relations can be seen as nodes with two arms wich they use to connect two other nodes. Nodes of a specific type (like a person node who holds a person's data) have their own nodemanager. A node manager can have functions wich are specific for the type of nodes it is managing. Just like a cloud can contain different type of nodes it can contain different type of relations. And just like specific type of nodes have their own nodemanager, relations of a specific type have their own relation manager.

tag.name: list
tag.info: Returns a list of nodes. Starting at one or more nodes traversals are made according to a specified path of nodemanagers. One traversal makes up one record returned by the list. All possible traversals that can be made starting at one or more nodes of the same type and following a specified path are returned. Additional attributes can be used to exclude records from the returned list or to influence the order of the returned list. Because the returned records can contain more than one node you will have to prefix the field name with the nodemanager name and a dot if you want to refer to them. When using a jsp variable a underscore has to be used to separate a nodemanager name from a field name.

attribute.name: startnodes
attribute.info: Comma-separated list of nodes that should be used as start nodes. The start nodes don't have to be a member of the first nodemanager in the path. For example, if the start nodes belong to the second nodemanager in a path with a length of three nodemanagers, traversals will go into two directions at the same time. All traversals that make up a complete path are returned. If a node belongs to the last nodemanager in a path traversals will go from right to left starting at the last nodemanager. All start nodes specified in this attribute have to belong to the same nodemanager. Nodes that belong to a different nodemanager than the first node are ignored In case this attribute is not specified all nodes from the first nodemanager in the path are used as start nodes.

attribute.name: path
attribute.info: A comma-seperated list of nodemanagers which specifies the path that should be followed. It is possible to explicitly specify a relationmanager that should be used to go from one node to an other. If no relationmanager is specified between two nodemanagers, all possible relationmanagers that can be used to go to the next specified node in the path are followed.

attribute.name: fields
attribute.info: Comma-separated list of fields that should be made available in the page. The fields are selected from attributes of the corresponding node managers defined in type. It is required to append a prefix to each field listed e.g. fields="mags.title,news.title". In the jsp page the values are available in form of Strings e.g. mags.title is available as mags_title and can be accessed using <%= mags_title %>.

attribute.name: constraints
attribute.info: Contraints to prevent records from being included in the returned list. These constraints follow the syntax of the SQL where clause. It's a good practice to use uppercase letters for the operators and lowercase letters for the fieldnames.

examplevalue.info: indicating the email field should be empty
indication the email should end with .org
indicating the email field should not be empty
indication the email should not end with .org
this will also allow 'Admin' to be returned
this will only allow name with a length greater than 5 to be returned
Linking constraints together using AND and OR
To only retrieve the string aaa'bbb. A single quote can be escaped using it twice for every single occurence.

attribute.name: orderby
attribute.info: A comma-separated list of field names on which the returned list should be sorted.

attribute.name: directions
attribute.info: A comma-separated list of values indicating wether to sort up (ascending) or down (descending) on the corresponding field in the orderby parameter or null if sorting on all fields should be up. The value DOWN (case insensitive) indicates that sorting on the corresponding field should be down, all other values (including the empty value) indicate that sorting on the corresponding field should be up. If the number of values found in this parameter are less than the number of fields in the orderby parameter, all fields that don't have a corresponding direction value are sorted according to the last specified direction value.

attribute.name: distinct
attribute.info: If set to 'true' or 'yes' all records who have exactly the same values will not be added a second time to the returned list.

attribute.name: max
attribute.info: The maximum number of records to return.

attribute.name: offset
attribute.info: The first number of records to skip.

attribute.name: searchdir
attribute.info: Determines how directionality affects the search. If set to "destination" relations in a path will only be followed if valid relation exist from source to destination. If set to "source" relations in a path will only be followed if valid relations exist from destination to source. To follow all relations ignoring their directionality set this attribute to "all". Any other value for this attribute will follow relations the way they are defined (either source to destination, destination to source or both).

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: See the 'id' attribute of the Node tag.

attribute.name: jspvar
attribute.info: See the 'jspvar' attribute of the Node tag.

tag.example: <mm:list startnodes="123" path="mags,posrel,news" sorted="posrel.pos" fields="news.title"> <mm:head>news in this magazine, ordered</mm:head> <%= news_title %> </mm:list>

tag.name: related
tag.info: The related tag is the same as the list tag except that it always needs one or more start nodes from wich the nodemanager will be taken and prefixed to the path specified bij the path attribute.

attribute.name: startnodes
attribute.info: If no startnodes attribute is given the related tag will look for a surrounding node provider tag and use the node provided by that tag as his start node.

attribute.name: path
attribute.info: This attribute is the same as the path attribute of the list tag except that the first nodemanager should be left behind. The first nodemanager is taken from the start nodes.

tag.name: listnodes
tag.info: The listnodes tag can be used to retrieve nodes managed by a certain nodemanager. The syntax of the attributes are the same as the syntax of the attributes of the list tag except that it is not needed to prefix the fieldnames with nodemanager names.

attribute.name: type
attribute.info: The name of the nodemanager managing the type of nodes that should be listed.

tag.name: relatednodes
tag.info: The relatednodes tag can be used to retrieve nodes of a certain type related to a node of another type. The syntax of the attributes are the same as the syntax of the attributes of the list tag except that it is not needed to prefix the fieldnames with a nodemanager name.

attribute.name: node
attribute.info: The node from wich the related nodes should be returned. If this attribute is not set the relatednodes tag will look for a surrounding node provider tag and use the node provided by that tag.

tag.example: <mm:node number="Magazine" > <mm:relatednodes type="news" fields="title" > <mm:head>news in this magazine</mm:head> <%= title %> </mm:relatednodes>

tag.name: nodefield
tag.info: Shows a field from a node without the need of use a node tag with a field tag in its body.

info.p: Groups tags, and facilitates communication to the outside world.
Tags inside a context tag supplying the 'id' attribute register themselves in the context. Other tags can refer to this id. See for example how the createrelation tag works.
With the import tag you can explicitily put things from outside this context into this context, e.g. from the parameter list or from a parent context.
There are several ways to refer to objects in the context.
When you are adding a new object then the used attribute is 'id'.
The 'id' of an 'external' object like a request parameter is referred to as 'externid' (only in the import tag).
If you are reusing the same object, for example you have put a node in the context, and are using it again then an attribute 'referid' is used.
If some attribute wants to refer to the value of an object in the context, and it is an attribute which can refer to the context, then you can make the attribute's value <context-id;>.<object-id>.

And finally there are some attributes which can only refer. For example if some tag has to live as a child of another tag but you want it to refer not to its direct parent, then there should be an attribute with the name of the parent in which you can put the id of the parent which it has to refer to. For example the field tag has an attribute 'node'. Other tags, like the createrelation tag have attributes like 'source' and 'destination' attributes which also simply contain the node id's. Please find the examples.
In TCP there is a 'tag' called 'create', which is comparable to 'context'.
A Cloud (or a transaction) is a context too, so normally it will suffice to use a cloud.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: The default id for a context is 'context'. If the context is a cloud, then the default id is 'cloud'. This id is used in context referring attributes.

tag.name: createrelation
tag.info: Creates a relation between two nodes.

attribute.name: role
attribute.info: The role for the new relation.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: The id of the node which is this relation.

attribute.name: source
attribute.info: The id of the node which will be on the source side of the relation.

attribute.name: destination
attribute.info: The id of the node which will be on the source side of the relation.

tag.example: <mm:cloud> <mm:transaction id="my_transaction"> <mm:createnode nodemanager="news" id="my_news"> <mm:setfield name="title">Todays news</mm:setfield> <mm:setfield name="subtitle">There happened a lot today</mm:setfield> </mm:createnode> <mm:node number="1808" id="my_author" /> <mm:createrelation role="author" source="my_author" destination="my_news" /> </mm:transaction> </mm:cloud>

tag.name: createnode
tag.info: Creates a new node.

attribute.name: nodemanager
attribute.info: The type (NodeManager name) of the new node.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: See the 'id' attribute of the Node tag.

attribute.name: jspvar
attribute.info: See the 'jspvar' attribute of the Node tag.

tag.name: setfield
tag.info: Changes the field 'name' from node 'node' (can also be list).

attribute.name: node
attribute.info: The 'id' of the node or list from which this field must be taken. By default this is the node or list which is enclosing this field.

attribute.name: name
attribute.info: The name of the field to set. If this field is not set this tag will look for a surrounding fieldlist tag to retrieve name and node from.

tag.name: transaction
tag.info: The transaction tag creates a transaction. A transaction is a context too.

attribute.name: name
attribute.info: The name of the transaction.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: The id of the transaction. Will be used to put it in a context, if possible.

attribute.name: jspvar
attribute.info: The name of the Jsp variable to export. If not specified, then a variable with name 'trans' will exist.

attribute.name: commitonclose
attribute.info: If the transaction must be committed after the body. The default is true.

tag.name: cancel
tag.info: Can cancel a transaction with this.

attribute.name: transaction
attribute.info: The id of the transaction.

tag.name: commit
tag.info: Can commit a transaction with this.

attribute.name: transaction
attribute.info: The id of the transaction.

tag.name: deletenode
tag.info: This tag extends the `node' tag, and is precisely the same. The only difference is that after the body the node will be removed.

tag.name: fieldlist
tag.info: A list of fields. A field can list inside a NodeProvider in which case the NodeManager if found by means of the parent node. It can also be stand alone, then you have to supply the 'nodemanager' attribute.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: The id of the fieldlist.

attribute.name: type
attribute.info: The type of fields that should be returned. If not specified, all fields are returned.

possiblevalue.info: Defined in NodeManager from the bridge classes, but not used in BasicNodeManager. Currently it does nothing special.
Return only those fields that should appear in the input area of the editor.

Return only those fields that should appear in the search area of the editor.

tag.name: fieldinfo
tag.info: This thing can be used inside a FieldListTag, or directly inside a NodeProvider if you indicate with the field attribute about which field you want to have information. It can have a body, which will be added to the produced value, if this is not null.

possiblevalue.info: The name of the field
The GUI name of the field (can be in other language)

A form entry for the field. This can only be used if the FieldList was in a NodeProvider tag, of if you have provided the 'nodemanager' attribute. If the FieldList has an id, the names of the form entries will be prefixed with it.

info.p: If you have create a form with type="input" and this form was submitted, then you can use type="useinput" under a NodeProvider, and it will get the request/post parameter produced by "input" and make the right changes to the node.
The necessary externid's for this will be implicity imported in the context. You don't have to worry about them.

possiblevalue.info: A form entry for the field, fit for use for searching. That means that not textareas will be used and such.

If you have create a form with type="searchinput" and this form was submitted, then you can use this. It will produce a part of a where clause which you can use to construct a whole 'where' for the list tag you are going to use.
The value of this field. Can only be used if in a NodeProviderTag.
The guivalue of this field. Can only be used if in a NodeProviderTag.

attribute.name: field
attribute.info: The field about which you want to have information. Only if you want to use this tag directly under a nodeprovider tag.

tag.name: present
tag.info: Checks if a certain id is present in the parent Context tag.

tag.name: notpresent
tag.info: Checks if a certain id is missing in the parent Context tag.

tag.name: write
tag.info: Can be used to create an jsp variable from a variable in the context.

attribute.name: context
attribute.info: If you want to get it from another context than the direct parent.

attribute.name: referid
attribute.info: The key of the variable to get.

attribute.name: jspvar
attribute.info: The name of the variable to create/used. If not specified, then the value will only be written to the page.

attribute.name: type
attribute.info: The type of the variable to create (default java.lang.Object)

tag.name: import
tag.info: To put objects in the context.

attribute.name: id
attribute.info: This is the key by which the object will be registered in the context. This key may not already exist. You must use the remove tag first, if you need to change the value of the registered object. If you do not supply this attribute, it is supposed to have the same value as 'externid' which should be present then.

info.p: The 'externid' is the name of an attribute in the session, parameter in the request, or id in the parent context. The value of this thing is imported in the current context, with the id given by the attribute 'id'.
If there is no attribute 'externid' then the value of the new object in the context is taken from the body of this import tag.

attribute.name: required
attribute.info: If this object is required to be present. If it has to be present, then the present tag will always evaluate. If there can nothing be found by externid and a default value in the body is missing too, then an exception will follow if required is true.

attribute.name: from
attribute.info: Where to search the externid in. On default it is searched in several sources, but you can limit it by this. In this way it is also possible to get different variables with the same name from different sources.

attribute.name: jspvar
attribute.info: If you specify 'jspvar' a jsp-variable with this name will be created too. It is available after the closing of the tag.

attribute.name: type
attribute.info: If you specify 'jspvar' you can also specify a type for it. Default, this is a String, but you could e.g. also want an Integer.

tag.name: remove
tag.info: Remove an object from the context.

tag.name: url
tag.info: Returns an URL with parameters from the context.

attribute.name: referids
attribute.info: Specify which parameters, otherwise all parameters.

attribute.name: extraparameters
attribute.info: You can also add some new parameters like this. A list of key=value.

attribute.name: page
attribute.info: The url to refer to. If not specified, then it becomes the result of getRequestURI. Since this attribute can refer to the context with a dot, you must escape dots in a filename with a backslash(\).

tag.name: param
tag.info: Adds a parameter to the parent URL Tag.

attribute.name: name
attribute.info: The name of the parameter. The value is the body.
